concept.title: Indexes
concept.shortdesc: An index can be generated from index entries that occur in topic bodies, topic prologs, or DITA maps.

conbody.p: The specialized indexing domain also provides elements to enable additional indexing function, such as "See" and "See also".

ul.li: An indexterm element that does not contain child indexterm elements, contributes a page number to the generated index.
An indexterm element that contains child indexterm elements, contributes to the hierarchy of the mult-level index entry that is generated.

section.title: indexterm elements in topic prolog or map
section.p: An indexterm that occurs in a topic prolog is interpreted as a point reference to the title of the topic. Likewise, in a DITA map, an indexterm that occurs in topicmeta inside of a topicref is interpreted as a point reference to the title of the referenced topic.

section.title: indexterm elements without ranges
section.p: The following material applies to indexterm elements that are not associated with a range:

ul.li: The index entry is generated using the content of the indexterm element.
The index entry points to the location of the indexterm element.
If multiple indexterm elements exist with the same content, only a single index entry is generated, although all locations associated with the indexterm element contribute to the index entry.

section.title: Index ranges
section.p: The start and end attribute on indexterm can be used to index an extended discussion.
The start of a range is indicated by an indexterm with a start attribute. The end of a range is indicated by one of the following:

ul.li: An indexterm with an end attribute whose value matches that of the start attribute on the indexterm element that begins the range.

In the absense of the indexterm with an end attribute, the applicable scope boundary. The applicable scope boundary depends on the location of the indexterm element that begins the range and the DITA map hierarchy.
Location of start element Default end-of-range
In the body of a topic End of the topic body
In the topic prolog End of the topic cluster. This includes the topic that contains the indexterm element and any nested topics.
In topicmeta element within a topicref element The end of the DITA map.

section.p: Index range indications can occur in the topicmeta of a topicref at the map level, in the prolog of a topic, or in the body of a topic, and are interpreted as follows (see for samples):

ul.li: In a map, the start range points to the start of the topic title of the topic being referenced by its containing topicref. The end range points to the end of the final child contained by the topic being referenced by its containing topicref, or to the end of the final topic referenced by the current map (whichever comes first). When a start and end range occur in the same topicmeta, the range applies to the containing topicref and its children.

In the prolog of a topic, the start range points to the start of the containing topic's title. The range ends with a matching index range end in the same prolog, regardless of whether the end range is specified. The range applies to the containing topic and all its children including child relationships defined in a map.

In the body of a topic, the range starts where the start indexterm occurs and ends at the matching index range end indication within the same body, or at the end of the body, whichever comes first. Such an index range does not span sub-topics of the topic.

dlentry.dd: (Unless combined with index-see) Instructs a processor to generate an index entry with a page reference. indexterm elements can be nested to create secondary and tertiary index entries.
Instructs a processor to generate a redirection to another index entry. The redirection typically does not have a page reference.
Instructs a processor to generate a redirection to another index entry. Both the index entry and the redirection have page references.
An indexterm element can contain multiple index-see-also elements.
